**Review of *Love Hurts* – ★★☆☆☆** *Love Hurts* is exactly what you'd expect from a 90-minute action comedy — fast-paced, predictable, and a little messy. Ke Huy Quan is always a joy to watch, and Sean Astin’s cameo is a fun meta wink for us *Goonies* fans. The plot is thin and generic, but that’s not the real issue — it’s more about how the movie just doesn’t click. It’s got all the right pieces, like an old-school Jackie Chan flick, but it’s missing the glue to hold it together. The dialogue? Yikes. Cringe city. Ariana DeBose’s performance didn’t help either — this is becoming a pattern with her recent work. That said, the romantic subplot between Ashley and Roger was surprisingly charming — honestly, I cared more about that than any of the action. It’s not a total disaster, but it’s the kind of movie you watch once and forget about the next day.

Love Hurts - 4/10. This hurts to say, but Love Hurts is a bland and mediocre rehash of way superior films. Its great to see Ke Huy Quan as a leading action hero, but for this to be his first live action role since EEAAO, this is devastating. In fact, to see both Quan and Ariana De Bose in a film like this is sad. Both won Academy Awards, so to see them in a production like this is sad because they’ve proven their mettle as performers, yet, are given really nothing to work with here. The action scenes are decent, but just feel like they’ve been ripped from other better movies. The story of a “hidden violent past person trying to move on with life” individual is getting tiresome now and severely redundant. There’s no chemistry between Quan and Bose sadly too, and I can’t blame them for that at all. The direction is kinda just pedestrian, and you can’t help but think that maybe there was a good product here, but its not executed to the manner that it should be. Hopefully Quan and Bose get better material in the future. Funny “Beast Mode” sequence here (the casual NFL fan in me laughed at that moment). Other than some okay fight scenes, there’s nothing really here!

Ke Huy Quan is charming, the action is excellent visceral and fun, and most of the supporting cast was stellar, especially Mustafa Shakir and Sean Austin. The little side stories of the background characters and great little comedy beats in the fight sequence were a delight. It is sad how truly excellent this film could have been and I hope its lack of financial success doesn't ruin our chances of seeing future Ke Huy Quan lead action movies of this type. I do really feel he could be a new Jackie Chan given the chance. That all being said, even though I enjoyed it despite its flaws, it would be unfair to pretend it wasn't really uneven. For starters, the obvious, who signed off on casting the leading lady/Quan's love interest an awkward uncomfortable 20+ years younger than him? Even if it wasn't icky it doesn't work plot wise either. She was supposed to be a lawyer before they both went on the lamb for an untold number of years? She must have gone to law school straight from junior high. The sappy orchestral score, odd voiceovers delivering information that would have been better conveyed almost any other way, pacing issues and a lackluster (and also weirdly young) big bad brother character, also marred what otherwise was a super fun action comedy. Worth watching dispite all but I hope Quan gets a movie more worthy of his potential as a leading man someday.

So let me start by saying that Ke Huy Quan is hands down the best thing about this uneven film. Based on his performance alone, I would say you should go see it. That being said, this film either had a director suffering from ADHD or a very interfering studio. There is a lot to like in this movie, and there are some plot points and story arcs that are quite compelling, but it feels like they left too much on the editing room floor. With better editing and more focus on the characters and story, this could have been a great film. As it is, it’s little more than an opportunity to showcase just how good an actor Ke Huy Quan is, because without him, this film would probably be complete garbage.

This movie starts off like a comedy, which is fine if that’s what it’s aiming for, but when you go in expecting action and get slapstick humor instead, it feels off. The tone is all over the place. The story follows Marvin Gable (Ke Huy Quan), a former hitman turned real estate agent, but it doesn’t do much with that concept. It throws him into a situation where his past comes back to haunt him, yet there’s no proper setup, no real stakes, and no explanation for why things happen the way they do. The transitions are rushed, and the pacing feels like the script was pieced together without a clear vision. There’s barely a plot, just a series of chaotic events with little to no build-up. The directing is a mess. Scenes escalate with no logic, and major moments happen so fast they don’t have any weight. Cinematography is just as frustrating, especially with the camera constantly circling Marvin whenever he’s deep in thought, which happens way too often. At one point, the movie spends nearly half of the second act on him repeating that he needs to “face his past.” It’s exhausting. The fight scenes aren’t much better. One guy throws knives at the ground, what was he aiming at exactly? others conveniently forget they have guns, or they point straight and shoot as if they're part of a first person shooter game. The action is so choreographed and predictable that it loses any tension. The acting doesn’t help either. Ke Huy Quan does his best, but the role just doesn’t fit him. The supporting cast feels like they’re forcing their performances, especially in the few moments where the movie tries to develop its characters. It’s like they added emotional depth as an afterthought instead of making it feel natural. Then there’s the script, which is a whole other issue. The dialogue is repetitive, with Marvin narrating every single thing he’s about to do instead of just doing it. It makes the movie feel dumbed down, as if the audience needs to be spoon-fed every thought and decision. Even the music choices are questionable. The score doesn’t match the tone of the scenes, making everything feel even more disconnected. It’s as if someone randomly picked tracks without considering how they fit into the story. By the time the big climax rolls around, the movie has already lost all sense of direction. When Marvin finally fights his past (literally and figuratively), it plays out in the most ridiculous way possible, with one-on-one fights that ignore any logical strategy. In the end, Love Hurts is a frustrating watch, disjointed, poorly executed, and lacking any real impact.

From debuting as Indiana Jones’ sidekick Short Round and becoming a Goonie to defending the multiversal continuum (both “Loki” and “EEAAO”), Ke Huy Quan is an evident child at heart, cherishing his career with sentiment towards his co-stars and amazing storytellers. Ever since he came out of retirement – after watching “Crazy Rich Asians” which inspired his return, his caliber has a lighthearted balance in reminiscent of his youthful beginnings with an actively evolved touch as he showcases his martial art skills. His rejuvenated stardom led to encouragement in the challenge of leading a film, but has “Love Hurts” deliver in that sought prospect? Marvin Gable (Quan) is a renowned dedicated realtor, but his peaceful life gets disrupted when he receives a familiar crimson envelope from Rose (Ariana DeBose), someone from the life he deserted including her being left for dead. Her recent stint drags him back into his crime lord brother’s (Daniel Wu) radar, sending hitmen to find Rose’s location, the problem being is that Marvin does not know her whereabouts much to the chaotic disbelief that threatens his happiness. As Rose calculated, the pressure triggers his past senses back upfront, further positioning him to realize he must truly pick which livelihood better suits him as it seems he did not completely bury his past. Your run-on-the-mill storyline when a past life comes barging but specially written as a holiday overlay with the integral celebrative core integrating some sort of meaning in between. Stunt coordinator Jonathan Eusebio directorially downplayed this as an uncommitted bloody Valentine of little meaning, seemingly centered around Quan’s affective mannerism of innocent charm and decently generic action that does not impress much besides later enabling an observative character study. There was comedic potential outside the narrowed yet apparently simplistic focus while the overall action is unimpressive for lacking any sort of adrenaline to do any stirring for the decreasing entertainment value as the repetitive script ridicules. The characterization is the inflicted attribution when the stock performances show conflicting participation either they mutually agree with the given material, or that they enjoy riding the star vehicle. DeBose’s performance is an arguable testament as she has shown fierce and passionate spirit in her previous, more favorable feats with this showcase proven to be resultingly dull. “Love Hurts” seems to be a creative buildup for Quan’s positional caliber that shall lead him into a better project regardless of the fun experience this supposedly instilled for the cast and crew, especially when the main appeals stem from his involving essence. The standout performance in the film was undoubtedly by Ke Huy Quan. I was interested in seeing this movie because it marked his first starring role. He had previously appeared as a supporting actor in Everything Everywhere All at Once, for which he won an Academy Award. Most famously, he was a child star in Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom and The Goonies. As a nod to the latter, Sean Astin also appears in this movie as a minor character and mentor to Marvin. That was a nice touch, although Astin’s character feels somewhat underutilized and random. Quan makes for an excellent leading man and is quick on his feet during the fight scenes. The stunts, reminiscent of Jackie Chan’s fighting style, create an exciting experience for the viewer. I love the charm and charisma that Quan brings to the screen; you can’t help but adore him. It's clearly made with love (pun intended) with a cast that put their acting and fighting chops into the genre specific pool. *** SOME SPOILERS PAST THIS POINT***Ke Huy Quan is charismatic and I truly believe his ability to go between the dark and light of his personality. Ariana DeBoise is fantastic as the femme fatal in the piece. Sean Astin was spot on perfect! And the dark love story between Lio Tipon & Mustafa Shakir was so beautifully balanced with dark, comedy and love. I have two criticisms, 1. This tends to be a trend in films overall: in the writing of DeBoise Character as the general stereotypical Femme Fatale with an edge, there was less depth and the role was used as more of an exposition role for Quan's past rather than a full fleshed out character. We all know DeBoise is talented and could have handled more. 2. Quan & DeBoise age difference, I get that its a real thing but it felt off to me. Overall, I say it's a must see for anyone who wants something nostalgic while also fresh and fun!

A Hilarious, High-Octane Valentine's Delight. Jonathan Eusebio’s Love Hurts is the kind of action-comedy that Hollywood needs more of—smart, stylish, and overflowing with charm. Blending breakneck fight sequences with razor-sharp wit, this film delivers a delightful mix of heart-pounding action and laugh-out-loud moments, anchored by a stellar ensemble cast. At the center of the mayhem is Ke Huy Quan, who shines as Marvin Gable, a reformed assassin turned real estate agent whose past literally comes knocking at his door. Quan brings an effortless blend of charm, physicality, and comedic timing to the role, making Marvin an instantly likable protagonist. Ariana DeBose is equally captivating as Rose, Marvin’s former target-turned-long-lost love, injecting the film with an irresistible blend of danger and allure. The supporting cast elevates the film even further. Daniel Wu’s ruthless yet magnetic portrayal of Alvin "Knuckles" Gable makes for a formidable antagonist, while Mustafa Shakir’s smooth but untrustworthy Renny Merlow adds layers of intrigue. However, one of the biggest scene-stealers is Marshawn Lynch, who, as the knife-wielding, poetry-loving Raven, delivers an unexpected comedic performance that lands every time. His dynamic with Kausar Mohammed’s hilariously disillusioned assistant Ashley brings a fresh and quirky romance into the mix. Eusebio, best known for his stunt choreography in John Wick and Birds of Prey, makes his directorial debut with a film that showcases his mastery of action. The fight sequences are kinetic and creative, blending gun-fu, brutal hand-to-hand combat, and even a real estate closing that turns into an all-out brawl. The choreography is crisp, inventive, and never overstays its welcome, keeping the film’s energy consistently high. Beyond the action, Love Hurts boasts a script filled with sharp dialogue and genuine laughs. The film balances its over-the-top violence with heartfelt moments, never losing sight of its central theme: embracing both the past and the future. The Valentine’s Day backdrop adds an ironic touch of romance, with love—whether rekindled, newfound, or hilariously misguided—woven into every plot thread. By the time the final showdown unfolds, Love Hurts has delivered a rollercoaster of adrenaline, humor, and heart. With its pitch-perfect cast, breathtaking action, and unexpectedly sweet moments, this film cements itself as a must-watch for fans of Mr. & Mrs. Smith and The Nice Guys.

Love Hurts is an emotionally resonant and beautifully crafted film that explores the intricate layers of love, loss, and healing. Ke Huy Quan delivers a career-defining performance, showcasing his incredible range and depth as an actor. His portrayal of a man navigating the complexities of a fractured relationship is both heartbreaking and inspiring, drawing you into every moment of his journey. The chemistry between Quan and his co-stars is palpable, adding authenticity to the film’s exploration of love’s joys and pains. The script is sharp and thoughtful, blending humor and heartbreak in a way that feels genuine and relatable. The direction is intimate, allowing the audience to connect deeply with the characters and their struggles. What sets Love Hurts apart is its ability to balance raw emotion with a sense of hope. Ke Huy Quan’s performance anchors the film, making every scene feel personal and impactful. The cinematography is stunning, with visuals that mirror the characters’ emotional arcs, and the soundtrack enhances the storytelling perfectly. By the end, you’ll be left reflecting on the universal truths of love and the resilience of the human spirit. Love Hurts is a five-star masterpiece, elevated by Ke Huy Quan’s extraordinary talent and the film’s heartfelt narrative. A must-watch for anyone who has ever loved and lost.

Love Hurts stands as another excellent installment in the Valentine film parody series, offering a highly entertaining viewing experience. It uniquely blends kung fu with an unconventional love story, amplifying the film’s comedic focus with action elements that drive its fast-paced nature. The film boasts a variety of styles to laugh at, complemented by impressive fights that rival real-life anime rather than traditional anime films. The pace is purely enjoyable, though other plots may inspire hope and well-being if you give them your attention. While this peculiar combination may not appeal significantly to the general audience, it depends on your tolerance for violence, excessive language, and its blend of silly humor and aggressive comedy within its brief runtime. The film possesses considerable potential, but it is undercut by the film’s brevity and the attempt to incorporate numerous characters and sub-plots. Is it the worst to hit theaters? Absolutely not, but it requires more polish, planning, and precision to earn a full recommendation for theatrical viewing. It will undoubtedly be action enthusiasts and comedy aficionados who find it irresistible as a niche audience, while most will likely appreciate it more at home.

Saw it with my husband (huge kung fu movie fan) tonight with mutual expectations that it would be like a goofy, late-Jackie Chan vehicle. I was amused from start to finish, even though I usually don’t go in for Tarantino-level gore (and this movie has a crazy amount of red corn syrup). I thought Ke Huy Quan’s character would quickly get on my nerves, but he won me over almost immediately with the infectious charm he brought to the character and the overall film. With a colorful cast of hilarious badasses (including Sean Astin, who never fails to please when there’s a major monologue to deliver), this was a thrill-a-minute, funny, suspenseful, surprising heartwarming movie that has already joined my favorites. (If I had to pick a “con”, it would be what others have said, the voiceovers spelled out a bit much for the audience in an unnecessary way. Could’ve done with about half as much.) One of my favorite details is how, over the course of the story, you can easily see how the deluded, squirrelly, happy-go-lucky persona Marvin has adopted could realistically pull an Ariana DeBose-level baddie like Rose: as we see more and more of who he used to be and how it shapes the person he is now, his characterization deftly avoids the painfully tired tropes of “dork gets the girl because he succumbs to violence and darkness and women only want bad boys” or “dork gets the girl because the writers think he deserves to win her” that it would have been so easy to fall into with this story. By showing us Marvin’s complexity, noble streak, loyalty, and strong bonds with the people he cares for, he becomes a fully-rounded character with both flaws and virtues that make sense to viewers. And in addition to DeBose carrying off a lethal femme fatale performance, we’re allowed to see a couple of moments where Rose is watching Marvin take enemies apart with terrifying competence and is clearly into it. We’re allowed to see why she is attracted to him at various points in the story, both through his deeds and his capabilities, and the fact that when she tells him what she needs from him, he comes through for her, for them both. It’s a weirdly effective chemistry for a little B-list action-comedy to deliver, and after countless lackluster performances from dead-eyed models-turned-actresses in action movies playing the only woman in the room who end up being narratively gifted to the leading hunk, I drank THIS story up like…well, boba. ;) A lot of folks recognize by now that if certain films critically pan but have high audience reviews, they’re actually a must-watch, and I’m so pleased that Love Hurts is 100% true to that formula.

Plagued by commitment issues, Love Hurts is an unfortunate slapdash affair that feels like it was thrown together at the last minute to meet a deadline, the emphasis leaning more towards the hurt than the love. The result is a film that feels aimless where none of the ideas come together as intended; the action, comedy and romance are too poorly intertwined and too contrasting in their contexts to result in a satisfying blend. Poor Ke Huy Quan does what he can to make this work but even he can't save this bad date; granted the film is not utterly devoid of charm, thanks to Quan's energy and the charisma he brings to the elaborate and well-choreographed if repetitive fight sequences. Sequences that feel more Bourne-like and less like a creation of the team behind John Wick; add in some horrific lighting and dreary cinematography, and the result is a film that is near impossible to tell what on earth is happening half the time. The connective tissue is flimsy, incoherent and frequently derivative, it's a poorly unexciting directorial debut from Jonathan Eusebio, that tries to do too much too fast. A tonal mush that wastes a likeable and first lead turn from Ke Huy Quan, Love Hurts amounts to what should be a breezy Valentine's comedy with some amusing, action set pieces, instead, having the ultimate charm of a breakup text.

Ever since Ke Huy Quan won the Academy Award, cementing his acting career comeback, I’ve been in full support of whatever he does. The new action romantic comedy LOVE HURTS is seriously testing that support. Marvin (Ke Huy Quan) is one of the best realtors in town. When his dark and violent past comes back and threatens the new life he’s built, he’s forced to face it head on. There is so much that doesn’t work in this movie. First, the story sucks. Marvin thought that having his face plastered around town was a good way of laying low after betraying his crime boss boba- drinking brother Alvin “Knuckles” (Daniel Wu). Marvin’s betrayal consisted of saving the life of his love interest Rose (Ariana DeBose), who comes back into his life like a wrecking ball because “Hiding ain’t living”. I have never seen two characters in a romance have less chemistry. I always try and use my big words, but not here: He feels like a “simp” and she feels like an a**hole who uses him like a tool. The side characters were a little more interesting and fun, which isn’t a good sign. Quan reunites with his GOONIES co-star Sean Astin, who actually has a good scene. Drew Scott (from the Property Brothers) has a funny scene, as does football player Marshawn Lynch. The antagonist has zero character development, which should’ve been easy to add in, since he’s Marvin’s estranged brother. The action scenes were not bad, but it felt like they were playing it safe. Even though the movie is 83 minutes long, it still feels too long. LOVE HURTS is a Valentine’s Day movie with commitment issues with half-baked subplots and a cookie-cutter ending. Just watch the trailer, that’s basically the movie.

I loved this film. It delivered what the trailer advertised and more. Watched it in theatres with my partner and we were squealing with joy regularly throughout over all the cute comedy and romance. Originally we'd expected this film to have just the one romantic plot line, but the film really leans into the Valentines Day mood with two additional romantic sub-plots that are just adorable. The first action-fight scene really sets the tone for the rest, with a blend of unique visuals and oddball comedy. Very reminiscent of Jackie Chan action comedies, where the protagonist brings across an underdog vibe with a lovable and sympathetic humor. The choreography of the fight scenes is memorable, with visuals and concepts that stand out in ways that many other fight scenes in more traditional action movies lack. This isn't just a guy-punches-guy-then-kicks-other guy. The choreography makes regular use of novel props that make the action unique, and weaves in comedy throughout. There's even a fight scene that through the use of a prop incorporates a very subtle nod to the Lao Che Club fight scene from Temple of Doom. Most importantly, the action feels grounded too. Marvin Gable is a top tier fighter, but he's not an untouchable god like some protagonists in action films are. He takes a real beating, and there's a genuine sense that the stakes are real. Victory is hard earned every time. I really hope I can find Marvin's sweater somewhere to give to my partner =^_^= All in all, this movie is a great film for huge sappy romantics who also happen to love action films.

Ultimately the script and direction felt lost and confused. The pacing was a mess and there was too much 'tell' and now enough 'show' with respect to what remained of the narrative. The tone was all over the place. The director doesn't seem to understand storytelling and this felt like it died a death by committee. In spite of the leads' overwhelming charisma, I struggled to root for anyone or care about anyone or about anything they did or wanted. Ultimately I think that the director should be handed a few much smaller projects (maybe a play or two) and spend a few years honing the craft of storytelling before he is handed the reigns of a bigger project.

Love Hurts is your classic action comedy where your main character used to be a hit man, assassin or gangster but they decided to leave that life behind for one reason or another but now their past has come back to them. We’ve seen this story a million times and honestly this one is no different nor does it improve on the previous model. Love Hurts is set around Valentines Day and it used that holiday theme pretty well. So much of the story’s themes are centered around love and relationships. The holiday forces a lot of our characters to confront the difficulty in their relationships or start new and unexpected romantic encounters to a hilarious degree. And yes, this movie has a lot of funny moments which is pretty important when you have an action comedy. The action in Love Hurts is actually pretty solid as well. I really liked that the fight scenes were all pretty lengthy and each of them went through several phases of a fight and used the environment pretty well. Nothing felt cheap or lazy at all. Ke Huy Quan is phenomenal in these action scenes. Which if you watched Everything Everywhere All At Once you’re not surprised by. Some of you might be surprised to know that Quan was a fight choreographer for several movies including the first X-Men movie. One big surprise for me was Marshawn Lynch who I knew was really good at comedic acting from his role in Bottoms and literally any interview that he’s ever done. But what I was super impressed with was how well he carried himself in the action scenes. He kept up with his cast mates really well and never seemed out of place. There’s a quirky assassin poet character named Raven who was equal parts cool and equal parts eye rollingly cringe. He alternated between those two seemingly scene by scene and sometime line by line. So yeah both the action and the comedy aspects were pretty solid. Where the movie is lacking though is in it’s story and some of the one note characters that we’re given. Ke Huy Quan plays our happy go lucky real estate agent Marvin, who’s a former assassin trying to get away from his old life yet still lives in the same town as everyone who knew him as the killer that he was. For a person who wanted to escape his old life sure didn’t go far. Ariana Debose’s character, Rose, is the catalysts that sets all of these events in motion when she comes back after everyone she worked for believed she was dead. And unfortunately while her reason for coming back is made very clear it’s just not satisfying enough for me to actually give a damn. And what’s worse was that it was actually annoying as hell. And the story tries to convince me that Marvin is in love with Rose. But besides him just saying or inner monologuing it I didn’t really see that at all. Or why he would be in love with her. Their “love story” is so under developed that I’m literally wondering why he’s throwing away this new life he built for her and at the same time mad at Rose for interrupting his new life. Like legit he’s better off without you. Love Hurts tries really hard to convince you that Rose is a badass but she just comes off as a cringe. With her all white thunderbird, and her playing chicken with another car trying to pull out the killer that Marvin used to be. It all just feels like a bad cookie cutter trope. Love Hurts feels like someone wrote this script back in 2005 and are just now dusting it off to give Ke Huy Quan and Debose something to do. Like they threatened their agents unless they found a movie for them immediately and they just picked this one up out of the discard pile. So overall Love Hurts is forgettable. It’ll end up as one of the hundreds of movies you scroll by half passed midnight looking for something to watch before you go to bed and if it’s lucky one day you’ll actually press play.

"Love Hurts" is a romantic action comedy without romance & comedy. Ke Huy Quan has too much of a likeable on-screen presence that the story does little to make it believable that he has a violent switch in his personality. The story rather plays itself off as being cartoony, that there's little faith on-screen to care about. There's no chemistry between Ke Huy Quan & Ariana DeBose, as they both get reduced to tiresome inner dialogue of exposition.

First of all, Ke Huy Quan is a gem and national treasure. I will not be accepting notes on this point. However, even he couldn't save this film. I will say the visuals are very pleasing and the choreography exciting, but that's about all I liked about this film. The characters storylines were disjointed, the chemistry between Ariana DeBose and Ke Huy Quan is lacking, and it felt like it ended, but didn't resolve. I really wanted to like this movie because its Ke Huy Quans first leading role, but this was not it. I didn't hate it, but I won't be watching it again.

A humorous action comedy. Ke is delightful as always in my opinion. But a few of the supporting actors didn't really hold up. Some of the roles felt wooden and some of the movie felt predictable. Nothing game changing, but there was still a good amount of entertainment to keep me watching.

I love Ke Huy Quan and will watch ANYTHING he is in… but aside from my love for this actor, the film just wasn’t good - at all. Nothing kept me engaged beyond the initial fight sequences or the opening of the film that came with copious amounts of that Ke charm. Then the film just dragged on… I daydreamed a lot through it. Really love Ke; don’t love this movie. I don’t even like it, even as good as it was to see him in a starring role, I wish it were in a different movie.

For not the first time, I see my taste is way different than the critics. We loved this movie! If you like kung fu action, if you like action/comedy movies like Mr. and Mrs. Smith and True Lies, this is a good one for you. Start to finish, lots of great fight scenes and romantic plot elements. And, yes, that is HGTV's Drew Scott for no reason but killing it.

The movie’s plot is carried by all its side plots. The main actors have no chemistry with each other at all. While the action scenes are entertaining and well coordinated, that is overshadowed by the fact that the two leads have no spark, and that no real connection is made with audience when it comes to their “love” story. What should have been a great film is maimed by a limp main plot and terrible lead casting. Disappointing, truly.
This was fun to watch! I love Ke Huy Quan!

This movie is one of MANY that has me very thankful for the FAST FORWARD button! After watching the trailer, I was really looking forward to seeing the movie... but was I EVER disappointed! There wasn't any story to speak of - just a great deal of Kung Fu fighting, LOTS of BLOOD and unnecessary violence wrapped around some kind of plot that's been done over and over to death. How many times did he have to say "I just want a normal life"? Very lazy writing - in a script that could have been 3 pages long, with a LOT of "copy, paste". Thank you FAST FORWARD!!
